The hazard then rolls initiative.

Maze-Weaver.name: Maze-Weaver
Maze-Weaver.publicNotes: The monstrous, bloated spiders from the windswept realm of Leng build eerie, dangerous lairs with the aid of magically compelled slaves. Leng spiders have anywhere from five to 13 legs, but never an even number.
Maze-Weaver.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->Interdimensional Web Sense.name: Interdimensional Web Sense
action->Interdimensional Web Sense.description: The maze-weaver senses when a creature touches its webs, even if it is on another plane of existence. While touching its webs, the maze-weaver has precise tremorsense to detect the vibrations of creatures touching its webs.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Create Web Weaponry.name: Create Web Weaponry
action->Create Web Weaponry.description: The Leng spider creates a weapon by applying a cord of webbing to heavy objects, such as rocks or chunks of metal, either attaching two heavy objects together to create a web bola or fastening one to its leg to create a web war flail.

action->Descend on a Web.name: Descend on a Web
action->Descend on a Web.description:
The Leng spider moves straight down up to 120 feet, suspended by a web line. It can hang from the web or drop off. The distance it Descends on a Web doesn't count when calculating falling damage.

The web can be severed by a Strike that deals slashing damage (AC 30, Hardness 15, 25 HP), causing the Leng spider to fall.

action->Lay Web Trap.name: Lay Web Trap
action->Lay Web Trap.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The Leng spider spins a web within 20 feet of itself to create a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.TFnr9Gq7VXPJu0GQ]{Grasping Snare}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.a2XaerM1KkPyLIPM]{Stunning Snare}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.XU8u9F3uoesGDjgM]{Warning Snare}. The Leng spider's web provides all the raw materials it needs. All save and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} DCs associated with web traps use the Leng spider's Crafting DC for traps (DC 36). A web trap decays after 24 hours.

action->Leng Spider Venom.name: Leng Spider Venom
action->Leng Spider Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:33]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2} (1 round); the confused effect has the emotion and mental traits.

action->Ranged Trip.name: Ranged Trip
action->Ranged Trip.description: A Leng spider can use a web bola to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ge56Lu1xXVFYUnLP]{Trip} a target with the Athletics skill. The skill check takes a -2 circumstance penalty. A web bola deals no damage when used to Trip.

action->Web Step.name: Web Step
action->Web Step.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The maze-weaver teleports to a space containing its webs, even if it is on another plane of existence.

Megatsunami.name: Megatsunami
Megatsunami.descriptionHazard: A tsunami can be a devastating disaster but pales in comparison to the daunting wall of water created by a megatsunami. When a megatsunami begins, ocean water often recedes far away from the shore, much more dramatically than it would during low tide. This warning sign might occur only seconds or minutes before the full force of the megatsunami crashes onto the land in the form of a wave whose height can exceed a hundred feet.
Megatsunami.disable: @Check[Ocean Lore|dc:36] (expert) or @Check[nature|dc:38] or @Check[survival|dc:38] (master) to chart the flood path, @Check[crafting|dc:38] (master) to reinforce a shelter, or @Check[athletics|dc:40] (expert) to quickly ferry people or supplies to higher ground,
Megatsunami.routine:
(5+ minutes, @Check[flat|dc:18]) The megatsunami's wave overtakes and crushes everything in its path. It rips buildings off their foundations and tears up trees by their roots. Prepared creatures have managed to reach an area of high ground or another form of safety, but unprepared creatures in the area are caught up in the flood and battered by a combination of water and debris.

Unprepared creatures take @Damage[(5d12+30)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:43|basic] save) when the megatsunami hits and are thereafter surrounded by water. If they can't breathe water, they must hold their breath or begin to drown. Each round, a creature can attempt a @Check[athletics|dc:40] check to Swim up near the surface or to keep their head above water for the remainder of the minute once they reach the surface.

At the start of the next four minutes, the megatsunami has carried each unprepared character 250 feet inland. At this time, each unprepared character takes @Damage[(3d12+20)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic] save). A character who managed that minute to remain near the surface gains a result one degree of success better than their actual rolled result, with a critical success indicating they've managed to clamber out of the surge onto high ground and are now prepared.

At the end of the five minutes, attempt a @Check[flat|dc:18] to determine if a new wave repeats the routine. Characters already swept inland only become affected by these following waves once the rushing water reaches them, but until then they can Swim in the choppy floodwaters with a successful @Check[athletics|dc:30] check, potentially reaching safety or high ground before the next wave hits. Once a region is flooded by a megatsunami, it typically remains flooded for several hours.
Megatsunami.stealth: @Check[Ocean Lore|dc:36] (expert), @Check[nature|dc:38] (expert), or @Check[survival|dc:40] (master) to notice anomalies in wave patterns

Meteor Shower.name: Meteor Shower
Meteor Shower.descriptionHazard: Impact from a sufficiently large asteroid would be powerful enough to wipe out a region or destroy a planet, but smaller-scale impact events, like from a meteor shower, present hazards that could be survived. This shower might arise naturally, or it might be the result of the PCs or other forces preventing a greater calamity by breaking a world-rending asteroid into smaller pieces.
Meteor Shower.disable: @Check[Astronomy Lore|dc:40] (master) or @Check[nature|dc:50] (legendary) to predict the trajectory of the falling asteroids and determine safe zones, @Check[athletics|dc:45] (legendary) or @Check[crafting|dc:47] (master) to dig underground shelters, @Check[diplomacy|dc:45] (master) or @Check[intimidation|dc:47] (master) to coordinate an orderly evacuation
Meteor Shower.routine: (1+ minutes, @Check[flat|dc:17]) Small asteroids rain down across the sky, battering and incinerating those caught in their path before carving craters. Over the course of a minute, enough asteroids smash into the ground and explode to inflict @Damage[6d10[bludgeoning],14d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to any unprepared characters in the area (@Check[reflex|dc:44|basic] save). The @Template[type:burst|distance:40]{40-foot-radius} craters left behind are greater difficult terrain.
Meteor Shower.stealth: @Check[Astronomy Lore|dc:41] (master) or @Check[nature|dc:45] (legendary) to notice signs of the approach of unusual celestial bodies

Meteor Shower (Escalation).name: Meteor Shower (Escalation)
Meteor Shower (Escalation).descriptionHazard: Impact from a sufficiently large asteroid would be powerful enough to wipe out a region or destroy a planet, but smaller-scale impact events, like from a meteor shower, present hazards that could be survived. This shower might arise naturally, or it might be the result of the PCs or other forces preventing a greater calamity by breaking a world-rending asteroid into smaller pieces.
Meteor Shower (Escalation).disable: @Check[Astronomy Lore|dc:40] (master) or @Check[nature|dc:50] (legendary) to predict the trajectory of the falling asteroids and determine safe zones, @Check[athletics|dc:45] (legendary) or @Check[crafting|dc:47] (master) to dig underground shelters, @Check[diplomacy|dc:45] (master) or @Check[intimidation|dc:47] (master) to coordinate an orderly evacuation
Meteor Shower (Escalation).routine:
(1+ minutes, @Check[flat|dc:17]) Small asteroids rain down across the sky, battering and incinerating those caught in their path before carving craters. Over the course of a minute, enough asteroids smash into the ground and explode to inflict @Damage[7d10[bludgeoning],14d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to any unprepared characters in the area (@Check[reflex|dc:46|basic] save). The @Template[type:burst|distance:40]{40-foot-radius} craters left behind are greater difficult terrain.

The material raining down from outer space includes chunks of adamantine. Adamantine's ability to break through the Hardness of materials is particularly lethal at terminal velocity. The falling adamantine has Hardness 20, allowing the asteroid's bludgeoning damage to overcome the Hardness of all materials with less Hardness, including shelters that would otherwise provide cover. Cover that's destroyed by the bludgeoning damage provides no protection against the fire damage.
Meteor Shower (Escalation).stealth: @Check[Astronomy Lore|dc:41] (master) or @Check[nature|dc:45] (legendary) to notice signs of the approach of unusual celestial bodies

Mirror of Glory.name: Mirror of Glory
Mirror of Glory.descriptionHazard: A reflective field of energy fills a large archway in a gatehouse, in which viewers regard themselves dressed in fine clothes, bowing down before Runelord Xanderghul.
Mirror of Glory.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:37] (master) to disrupt one of the six anchor points that link the paradigm cube to the mirror, @Check[arcana|dc:34] (legendary) to use knowledge of magic that opposes pride to unravel the mirror's power, @Check[intimidation|dc:37] (master) to use one's force of personality to stand against the arrogance amplified by the mirror, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (8th-rank; counteract DC 36) to counteract one of the six faces of the paradigm cube; six successes are required to disable the Mirror of Glory
Mirror of Glory.routine:
(6 actions) On its turn, the Mirror of Glory targets random PCs in the area with distortions of their reality, spending an action to target one PC. If it has actions remaining after targeting the PCs, it spends any remaining actions repairing damage done to itself at the rate of 25 HP restored per action spent. If the mirror hasn't been damaged, then these unused actions are lost. Each time the Mirror of Glory targets a PC with a distortion, roll 1d6 and consult the entries below to determine what the PC experiences and any subsequent effects. The trap loses one action for each successful check made to disable it, but this doesn't reduce the number of distortions it's capable of creating. When a PC experiences a distortion, they take @Damage[10d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:37|basic] save), but on a failed saving throw, the PC suffers that distortion's additional effect.

1—Beauty: The PC regards Xanderghul as the most attractive figure they've ever seen. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

2—Cruelty: The PC sees Xanderghul as a demonic figure capable of unimaginable cruelty, who lashes out at the PC with dozens of blades and poisoned needles meant to carve away their strength. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} for 24 hours.

3—Disappointment: To the PC, Xanderghul suddenly seems to be an intimidating parental figure, commanding officer, or other person with authority whose disapproval induces tremors of nervousness. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 24 hours.

4—Jealousy: The PC watches as a glorious plume of peacock tail feathers spreads behind Xanderghul, filling them with jealousy and potentially driving them to lash out unpredictably against their allies in hopes of becoming the only one worthy of Xanderghul's attention. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round. 5—Despair: The PC feels their own flesh rotting away as they realize the Xanderghul who stands before them exists outside of the laws of time. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

6—Worship: The PC is filled with the conviction that Xanderghul is the one true god and feels the urge to pray to him for absolution. Additional effect: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 3}.
Mirror of Glory.stealth: (master) to notice the reflective field is dangerous; noticing the field has a DC of 0

action->Bow Before Your God.name: Bow Before Your God
action->Bow Before Your God.description:
Trigger A creature touches the mirror or Seeks the reflection while being adjacent to the mirror

Effect The image of Xanderghul that appears behind the reflected PCs spreads his arms wide in glory, transforming the world presented in the reflection. Each PC reflected in the mirror (regardless of whether they're looking at the reflection or not) must attempt a @Check[will|dc:37] save to avoid being compelled to drop to their knees before Xanderghul's glory—on a failure, the PC becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}, and the feelings of inferiority cause them to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 24 hours. The trap then rolls initiative.

Misery Siktempora.name: Misery Siktempora
Misery Siktempora.publicNotes:
Creatures born of intense pain and suffering, the armless, six-legged misery siktemporas are some of the most numerous of their kind since misery is as ubiquitous an experience as living. They're also the most proactive of siktemporas, seeking to propagate the misery from which they spawn. They delight in opportunities to travel to the Material Plane, where misery is so woefully prevalent and easily multiplied.

In the Dimension of Time, intense emotions are more than just ethereal feelings. They accumulate over time, from things like the critical mass of emotion caused by a historic event or a settlement passing down a powerful sentiment for generations. These accretions eventually give birth to siktemporas. Each siktempora feels, with all their being, a singular intense emotion linked to the circumstances that spawned them. A rare few, however, are created when an emotionally invested creature attempts to travel to the Dimension of Time or interferes with the flow of time, which can create paradoxes or manipulate past events.

Siktemporas usually isolate themselves on the Dimension of Time in mindscapes infused with the emotion that created them, but some travel to other planes. These wanderers long to indulge in more of their core emotion or to engender more of that feeling, thus perpetuating their own kind.
Misery Siktempora.hpDetails: regeneration 40 (deactivated by mental, orichalcum, or vitality)

action->Temporal Sense.name: Temporal Sense
action->Temporal Sense.description: A siktempora can always roll Dimension of Time Lore for initiative. When it does, it gains a +2 circumstance bonus to the roll.

action->Regeneration 40 (Deactivated by.name: Regeneration 40 (Deactivated by Mental, Orichalcum, or Vitality)

action->Slash the Suffering.name: Slash the Suffering
action->Slash the Suffering.description: Creatures with the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied} condition are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to the misery siktempora.

action->Uncanny Pounce.name: Uncanny Pounce
action->Uncanny Pounce.description:
Trigger The misery siktempora rolls Dimension of Time Lore for initiative

Effect The misery siktempora Strides once and makes a claw Strike, in either order.

action->Inflict Misery.name: Inflict Misery
action->Inflict Misery.description:
Requirements The misery siktempora's last action was a claw Strike that damaged the target

Effect The misery siktempora fills the target's thoughts with abject despair. The target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:32] save. Regardless of outcome, the target is then immune to Inflict Misery for 1 minute.

Success The target is unaffected.

Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 1 round.

Critical Failure As failure, but for 1 minute.

action->Telepathic Wail.name: Telepathic Wail
action->Telepathic Wail.description:
The misery siktempora assails the mind of one creature within 100 feet with a wail of anguish and torment that deals @Damage[8d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:32|basic] save).

On a failed save, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for the first action of its next turn (or for 1 round on a critical failure).

Natbakh.name: Natbakh
Natbakh.publicNotes:
Natbakhs are native to the peaks and subterranean caverns of the windswept dimension of Leng and haunt the dark skies of that nightmare realm.

Nightmare Eruptions

In places where the boundaries between Golarion and Leng are thin, such as the depths of the Kodar Mountains, natbakhs have a particularly horrifying method of entering the waking world. If they consume the dreaming persona of someone sleeping near such thin places, they can burst forth from that sleeper's body, killing them in life as well as in their dream, often leaving the now-dead dreamer's home in splinters before flying off to build a lair in the mountains. Such "nightmare eruptions" are rare, but it doesn't take many natbakhs to leave a mark in a region unprepared for their arrival.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The natbakh ends one condition affecting them.

action->Mythic Resilience (Reflex).name: Mythic Resilience (Reflex)
action->Mythic Resilience (Reflex).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Drain Dreams.name: Drain Dreams
action->Drain Dreams.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements The natbakh's previous action was a successful jaws Strike that damaged a creature

Effect The natbakh's suckered tongue latches on. The creature must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:34] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical failure) for 1 week as their dreams are slurped away. If the creature becomes stupefied in this way, the natbakh regains @Damage[32[healing]] HP. Draining dreams from a creature that's already stupefied doesn't restore any HP, but increases the victim's stupefied value by 1, to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 5}.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Mythic Skill.name: Mythic Skill
action->Mythic Skill.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The natbakh attempts its next Athletics or Stealth skill check with a +4 bonus and is considered to have mythic proficiency for that check.

action->Nightmare Screech.name: Nightmare Screech
action->Nightmare Screech.description:
The natbakh shrieks in a @Template[type:cone|distance:50] that echoes more in the minds of those in the area than in the ears. Those in the area recall shrieks like this in forgotten nightmares, and the memories of wounds suffered in dreams cause nauseating pain. Creatures in the area take @Damage[10d8[mental]|options:area-damage] damage and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:34] save. The natbakh can't use Nightmare Screech again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Nightmare Screech]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Success The creature takes no damage.

Success The creature takes half damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage, is sickened 2, and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for as long as they remain sickened (or 1 minute, whichever comes first).

action->Writhing Clutches.name: Writhing Clutches
action->Writhing Clutches.description: A natbakh can Fly at half Speed while it has a Huge or smaller creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or at full speed when it has a Medium or smaller creature grabbed or restrained, carrying that creature along with it.

Nightmare Feast.name: Nightmare Feast
Nightmare Feast.descriptionHazard: The consumption of sentient, and even sapient creatures is widespread in Leng. Those who suffer such fates are as much the genesis of this nightmare as those who partake, and as such, this nightmare tends to manifest in places where meals were taken, from banquet halls to campsites.
Nightmare Feast.disable: @Check[society|dc:43] (master) to fight these destructive urges by focusing your thoughts on traditions not so steeped in cruelty, or @Check[intimidation|dc:40] (legendary) to overwhelm the nightmare's influence with the strength of your own personality; three successes are required to disable the nightmare
Nightmare Feast.reset: The nightmare deactivates as soon as a round begins with no creatures in its area, and resets in [[/gmr 1d6 #rounds]]{1d6 rounds}.
Nightmare Feast.routine:
(1 action) The nightmare transitions from directly chewing on the creatures in the area to compelling them to feed for themselves. Each round on the nightmare's turn, all creatures within 30 feet of the nightmare's epicenter must attempt a @Check[will|dc:36] save with the following results.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The nightmare causes a momentary change to the creature's appearance, causing its jaws to take on a frightening, fanged appearance and filling the creature's mind with distracting, unsettling hunger that cause them to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of the nightmare feast's next turn.

Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} until the start of the nightmare feast's next turn and gains a +30 bite (magical) that deals @Damage[(3d12+10)[slashing]] damage plus @Damage[2d6[persistent,bleed]] damage on a hit. The creature favors this bite Strike when the confusion drives them to attack.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature also becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} and can use the extra action to make bite Strikes.

action->Invisible Feasters.name: Invisible Feasters
action->Invisible Feasters.description:
Trigger A living creature approaches within 10 feet of the remains of a previous feast

Effect Invisible attackers begin to bite and gnaw at the triggering creature and any other creatures within 30 feet. The creatures take @Damage[10d6[slashing]] damage from the biting (@Check[reflex|dc:36|basic] save), and then the nightmare rolls initiative.

Peacock Phoenix.name: Peacock Phoenix
Peacock Phoenix.publicNotes:
Unlike its namesake, the peacock phoenix is a being of pure magic, a unique manifestation of Xanderghul's alter ego as the Peacock Spirit.

Other Mythic Phoenixes

Because it's tied so intrinsically to Runelord Xanderghul and his alter ego, the Peacock Spirit, once the peacock phoenix is destroyed, it's doubtful Golarion will ever see its like again. Whether different kinds of mythic phoenixes, born from similar confluences of magical and psychic energy, could ever exist remains uncertain.
Peacock Phoenix.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The creature ends one condition affecting it.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Mythic Resilience (Reflex).name: Mythic Resilience (Reflex)
action->Mythic Resilience (Reflex).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Radiant Panoply.name: Radiant Panoply
action->Radiant Panoply.description: 20 feet. The peacock phoenix is surrounded by an aura of iridescence. An adjacent creature that starts its turn in the aura must attempt a @Check[will|dc:35] save. On a failure, the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} until the start of its next turn.

action->Rebirth.name: Rebirth
action->Rebirth.description: When the peacock phoenix dies while incorporeal, they return to life at the start of their next turn with full Hit Points. They are no longer incorporeal, lose the spirit trait, gain the beast trait, and lose their immunities and resistances (except for mythic resistance) and radiant panoply. Their Strength modifier becomes +7. They lose their radiant wing Strike and gain a beak and talon Strike.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Mythic Skill.name: Mythic Skill
action->Mythic Skill.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The creature attempts its next skill check with a +4 bonus and is considered to have mythic proficiency for that check. This applies to one skill when this ability is gained and a second skill if the creature is 12th level or higher.

action->Radiant Beam.name: Radiant Beam
action->Radiant Beam.description: The phoenix emits a @Template[type:line|distance:100] of radiance from their eyes. Creatures in the area take @Damage[10d12[force]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:38|basic] save). The phoenix peacock can't use Radiant Beam again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Radiant Beam]]{1d4 rounds}.

Phantom of Desire.name: Phantom of Desire
Phantom of Desire.publicNotes: A rumor can become so vivid and so persistent that it comes to life, creating a brainchild-a living illusion that hatches from an intense belief in a remorseless and implacable killer. Often, these rumors swirl around the victims of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.tlcrVRqW1MSKJ5IC]{Phantasmal Killer} spell. A brainchild's capabilities grow when they pursue a believer but deflate against skeptics, making them only as bad as one thinks they are. A simple drive to stalk, terrify, and kill propels a brainchild, but the creature might also exhibit other behaviors ascribed to them through gossip.

action->Universal Language.name: Universal Language
action->Universal Language.description: Anything spoken by the phantom of desire is perceived by the listener in its native language.

action->Urban Legend.name: Urban Legend
action->Urban Legend.description:
This phantom is a manifestation of the pernicious rumors throughout the Inner Sea region that Sorshen is hiding her true intentions as ruler of New Thassilon and is biding her time for a chance to reveal her true motives to the world once she's lulled everyone into a false sense of security. A PC who Seeks or Senses Motive on a phantom of desire with a @Check[perception|dc:44] check realizes that the phantom of desire doesn't actually do additional bleed damage with her strikes, doesn't have her Enticing Charade ability, and doesn't have any innate spells at all. Unlike the typical brainchild, phantoms of desire are fully created by the animus of longing; they do not possess the typical Persistence of Memory ability most brainchildren have.

A brainchild is sustained only by the reputation that precedes them. Mindless creatures are immune to a brainchild and can't perceive them.

The brainchild's size, features, and items, as well as the appearance of their attacks, match what the foes perceiving them expect. If foes expect to see different things, the brainchild chooses which to manifest. If any creature that can perceive the brainchild believes the brainchild has one of the abilities below, the brainchild has that ability.

A creature can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1xRFPTFtWtGJ9ELw]{Sense Motive} (against the brainchild's Deception DC) to attempt to disbelieve an individual ability. If at any point no creature perceiving the brainchild believes in the ability, the brainchild loses that ability immediately. If foes expect different particulars, such as one believing the brainchild is immune to fire and another believing they're immune to divinations, the brainchild chooses one to have.

  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.j2wsK6IsW5yMW1jW]{Tremorsense} (imprecise) 100 feet
  • Immunity to one damage type, magic school, or condition
  • Weakness 10 to one damage type other than mental
  • Resistance 10 to physical damage, with an exception for either cold iron or silver
  • @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.etMnv73EIdEZrYYu]{Frightful Presence} (aura, emotion, fear, mental) 100 feet, DC 28
  • [[/r 1d6]]{1d6} Extra Damage on Strikes, of a type one foe believes in
  • Additional Spells @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.R8bqnYiThB6MYTxD]{Phantom Pain} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.IqJ9URobmJ9L9UBG]{Shadow Blast} at 6th rank

action->Delusional Aspiration.name: Delusional Aspiration
action->Delusional Aspiration.description: When a phantom of desire hits a creature with an intrusive thought Strike, the creature must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:38] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1}.

action->Enticing Charade.name: Enticing Charade
action->Enticing Charade.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The phantom telepathically reaches into the mind of another creature, offering to make their dreams come true. The target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:40] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} by the distraction (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} on a critical failure) until the start of the phantom's next turn.

Pridespawn Sentinel.name: Pridespawn Sentinel
Pridespawn Sentinel.publicNotes:
Sinspawn were created by one of seven ancient wizards known collectively as runelords—each of whom embraced and embodied one of seven sins. The first sinspawn was created by the Runelord of Wrath, utilizing techniques that have since gone on to influence fleshwarping practices. It wasn't long before the technique used to create sinspawn fell into the hands of the other runelords, and while each tried their own hand at crafting variants of their own design, today, sinspawn of wrath remain the most numerous and notorious of their kind.

Bearing only a vague resemblance to the humanoids from whose flesh they were formed, sinspawn generally appear horrifically emaciated and have unnaturally long arms and digitigrade legs, each with a trio of stubby, taloned digits. Veins bulge across sinspawn's bodies in sanguine patterns that suspiciously resemble twisted runes, and their flesh is pale and hairless. Their heads are elongated, with slits for a nose, red eyes, and disturbing lower jaws that split in half at the chin, revealing pedipalps that end in tiny, three-fingered hands and framing a long, lolling tongue.

Sinspawn stand 6-1/2 feet tall and typically weigh as much as an emaciated human of their size. They behave in a manner consistent with their associated sin and have physical characteristics that hint at these qualities. For example, greedspawn's veins appear to run with gold, while envyspawn appear even more gaunt than the rest of their kin.
Pridespawn Sentinel.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic, +4 status to all saves vs. mental

action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.name: Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet
action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.description:
A sinspawn can smell creatures that reflect its sin as the scent ability. The GM determines which creatures are appropriately sinful.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Scent]

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->+4 Status to All Saves vs. Menta.name: +4 Status to All Saves vs. Mental

action->Hallucinatory Backlash.name: Hallucinatory Backlash
action->Hallucinatory Backlash.description:
Trigger The pridespawn takes damage from a creature's weapon Strike

Effect The pridespawn rebuffs the arrogance of the foe that harmed it and scoffs at the attack. The triggering creature hallucinates their own attack coming back at them and takes @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:32|basic] save).

action->False Pride.name: False Pride
action->False Pride.description:
The pridespawn sentinel stumbles back and appears frightened and intimidated by a creature within 30 feet that it can see. The targeted creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:32] save; regardless of the result, that creature is temporarily immune to False Pride for 24 hours.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature becomes overconfident and careless as they believe themselves to be more intimidating than they actually are. They're @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against the next attack the pridespawn sentinel attempts against them this round.

Failure As success, but the creature's false pride causes them to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round as they spend one of their actions posturing and bragging about their superiority. They're off-guard as long as they remain slowed.

Critical Failure As failure, but for 1 minute.

action->Sinful Bite.name: Sinful Bite
action->Sinful Bite.description:
A creature hit by the jaws of a pridespawn sentinel must attempt a @Check[will|dc:29] save as it's assailed by arrogant thoughts.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

Critical Failure The creature is sickened 2 and also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} for 1 minute.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: A pridespawn sentinel deals 1d6 extra precision damage to creatures who are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}.

Pyroclastic Mukradi.name: Pyroclastic Mukradi
Pyroclastic Mukradi.publicNotes: Fearsome centipede-like creatures, mukradis are three-headed predators with a devastating array of ways to kill, burn, and dismember. A version of the mukradi that dwells in the Darklands is rumored to exist. It's said these variant mukradis have black scales, and all of their heads spew a black, acidic goo that animates before being reabsorbed by the mukradis.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The pyroclastic mukradi ends one condition affecting them.

action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude).name: Mythic Resilience (Fortitude)
action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Partitioned Anatomy.name: Partitioned Anatomy
action->Partitioned Anatomy.description:
Trigger The mukradi would be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned}

Effect The mukradi confines the debilitating effect to a certain portion of its nervous system, ignoring the effect but causing a maw of its choice to go dormant for the effect's duration. That maw can't be used for a Strike or to Breathe Energy during that time. This ability can't be used if all the mukradi's heads are dormant.

action->Spitting Rage.name: Spitting Rage
action->Spitting Rage.description:
Trigger A creature scores a critical hit on the mukradi

Effect The mukradi's Breathe Energy recharges. It can use Breathe Energy immediately as part of this reaction. It can't use this reaction again until it recharges Breathe Energy naturally.

action->Breathe Energy.name: Breathe Energy
action->Breathe Energy.description:
The mukradi breathes a blast of energy from one of its three heads; each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:36|basic|options:area-effect] save.

The mukradi can't Breathe Energy again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Breathe Energy]]{1d4 rounds}.

  • Flame Maw (fire) @Template[cone|distance:60] of fire dealing @Damage[16d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage.
  • Shock Maw (electricity) @Template[line|distance:120] of electricity dealing @Damage[16d6[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage.
  • Smoke Maw (poison) @Template[type:cone|distance:60] of toxic smoke dealing @Damage[16d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Pull Apart.name: Pull Apart
action->Pull Apart.description:
The mukradi makes two Strikes with different maws against the same target. If both hit, the target takes an extra @Damage[(2d12+13)[slashing]] damage, with a @Check[fortitude|dc:36|basic] save. On a critical failure, the creature is torn to pieces and dies.

The mukradi's multiple attack penalty increases only after all the attacks are made.

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The pyroclastic mukradi gains one additional use of Breathe Energy.

action->Thrash.name: Thrash
action->Thrash.description: The mukradi Strikes once against each creature in its reach. It can make one of these Strikes with each of its maws, one with its tail lash, and the rest with its legs. Each attack takes a –2 circumstance penalty and counts toward the mukradi's multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after all the attacks are made.

Queen Sorshen's Aid.name: Queen Sorshen's Aid
Queen Sorshen's Aid.descriptionHazard: Queen Sorshen is a beautiful Thassilonian woman wielding a shimmering guisarme. Her violet eyes are fierce and focused, but the corner of her lips twist up in a small, lopsided smile.
Queen Sorshen's Aid.disable: @Check[arcana|dc:55] to unravel the energies allowing Sorshen to continue to vex Xanderghul; 4 successes are required to disable the hazard.
Queen Sorshen's Aid.routine:
(3 actions) On her initiative each round, Sorshen can spend her three actions on any of the following options, following PC suggestions if requested. She cannot use any action from the following list more than once per round.

Aid Ally 1 Sorshen uses her magic to empower one of the PCs, granting that PC a +4 circumstance bonus to attack rolls until the start of her next turn. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.MNITD4PrcyRCqPbK]{Effect: Queen Sorshen's Aid (Aid Ally)}

Dispel Pride 1 Sorshen attempts to counteract a magic effect put in place by Xanderghul, with a counteract rank of 9th and a [[/gmr 1d20+40 #Counteract]]{+40} modifier for the roll.

Distracting Presence 1 Sorshen uses her power to distract Xanderghul, causing him to lose his resistance to mental damage until the start of her next turn and also to attempt a @Check[will|dc:50] save with the following results.

Critical Success Xanderghul takes no further penalty, and is temporarily immune to Distracting Presence for 24 hours.

Success Xanderghul is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of his turn.

Failure Xanderghul is off-guard until the start of Sorshen's next turn.

Critical Failure As failure, but Xanderghul is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} as long as he remains off-guard.

Indulgent Arcana 1 Sorshen empowers a PC's magic, so that the next spell with the mental trait they cast before Sorshen's next turn increases its save DC and attack roll by 2 and removes the spell's incapacitation trait, if any. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.KFmJLxZAFQ2Q7C1N]{Effect: Queen Sorshen's Aid (Indulgent Arcana)}

Sinuous Strike 1 Sorshen swings her guisarme, usurping some of Xanderghul's own power to manifest an illusory duplicate that attempts a guisarme Strike against him.
Queen Sorshen's Aid.stealth: +45 for initiative; noticing her has a DC of 0

action->Ally of Golarion.name: Ally of Golarion
action->Ally of Golarion.description:
Trigger Xanderghul rolls initiative

Effect Sorshen casts telepathy, allowing her to communicate with the PCs; she can inform them of her options during her routine and follows their advice and requests if given. She then rolls initiative.

Quoroc.name: Quoroc
Quoroc.publicNotes:
Giant octopuses are found in the heart of deep, dark oceans. Clever and adaptable, they hunt and devour all manner of animals. Despite growing up to 16 feet long, a giant octopus can compress its body to squeeze through small gaps as long as there's room for its beak.

Giant octopuses favor shipwrecks, coral reefs, or underwater caverns as lairs, where they can take advantage of narrow confines for protection. Like their smaller kin, they're fond of adorning and decorating their lairs with found objects—many of which, in the giant octopus's case, are also magical weapons, shields, or works of art salvaged from sunken ships or fallen adventurers.

action->Compression.name: Compression
action->Compression.description: A giant octopus can move through a gap at least 2 feet wide without Squeezing, and can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.kMcV8e5EZUxa6evt]{Squeeze} through a gap at least 1 foot wide.

action->Quoroc Toxin.name: Quoroc Toxin
action->Quoroc Toxin.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:36]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[3d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[3d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[3d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} 1 (1 round)

Ravenous Crypt.name: Ravenous Crypt
Ravenous Crypt.publicNotes:
When tomb robbers loot the dead, sometimes the resting places of those victims animate to avenge them. This happens most frequently when the entombed person was a particularly greedy, gluttonous, or vindictive individual in life. Other ravenous crypts arise spontaneously in places where energy from the Void flows freely into other planes.

Boneyard Guardians

Ravenous crypts are occasionally encountered in the Boneyard, roaming that vast necropolis like packs of hungry dogs, although they quickly come to heel while in Pharasma's presence. This behavior has led some scholars to posit that the constructs are created at the behest—or at least with the blessing—of the Lady of Graves. Magrim, the demigod of the dwarven afterlife, is also believed to have some connection to ravenous crypts, as suggested by the fact the pediments of many crypts are carved with the scowling visages of dwarven elders.

action->Construct Armor (Hardness 15).name: Construct Armor (Hardness 15)
action->Construct Armor (Hardness 15).description: The ravenous crypt reduces any damage it takes by an amount equal to its Hardness. Once it's reduced to less than 100 Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing its Hardness and reducing the crypt's Armor Class to 32.

action->Reduced to Rubble.name: Reduced to Rubble
action->Reduced to Rubble.description: When the ravenous crypt is reduced to 0 Hit Points, its space becomes an area of difficult terrain, and any creatures swallowed by the crypt fall @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} in a space of their choice within the area.

action->Sap Strength.name: Sap Strength
action->Sap Strength.description:
A creature that takes void damage from the ravenous crypt's Swallow Whole ability must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:34] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 3} for 1 minute.

action->Spacious Stomach.name: Spacious Stomach
action->Spacious Stomach.description: A ravenous crypt has a 10-foot-space inside of it. A creature swallowed by the ravenous crypt isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or slowed, and the creature doesn't need to hold its breath. It can attack the ravenous crypt normally. Because it isn't grabbed, it can't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} the crypt, but it can break free by dealing bludgeoning damage to the crypt equal to the crypt's Rupture value or by Forcing Open the crypt's doors with a successful @Check[athletics|dc:34] check.

action->Thrash.name: Thrash
action->Thrash.description: Each adjacent creature and each creature swallowed by the ravenous crypt takes @Damage[5d10[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:34|basic] save). Swallowed creatures take a –2 circumstance penalty to this save. On a critical failure, a creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Risen Runelord (Envy).name: Risen Runelord (Envy)
Risen Runelord (Envy).publicNotes:
Risen runelords are created by a powerful ritual invented by Runelord Xanderghul—a ritual called raise runelord. All risen runelords are at least level 11 creatures. Once created, a risen runelord has no capacity to become more powerful, as they are manifestations of their legacy at a specific point in time (although given enough time and resources, a risen runelord could potentially find a way to overcome this limitation on self-improvement).

A risen runelord has a modicum of free will, but as long as the one who created them via raise runelord lives, they're bound to their creator's desires. A risen runelord ordered to undertake obviously self-destructive actions might, at the GM's discretion, resist the command and could potentially even break free of their creator's control.

Since raise runelord draws upon a runelord's legacy as it exists within the Dreamlands, no risen runelord can ever sleep or dream. Once created, a risen runelord has no capacity to become more powerful, as they are manifestations of their legacy at a specific point in time (although given enough time and resources, a risen runelord could potentially find a way to overcome this limitation on self-improvement).

A risen runelord has a modicum of free will, but as long as the one who created them via raise runelord lives, they're bound to their creator's desires. A risen runelord ordered to undertake obviously self-destructive actions might, at the GM's discretion, resist the command and could potentially even break free of their creator's control.

Since raise runelord draws upon a runelord's legacy as it exists within the Dreamlands, no risen runelord can ever sleep or dream. Xanderghul can use a risen runelord in a special way: he can use any risen runelord (including ones he didn't create) as a spare body. If he's slain, his soul can instantly jump to the closest risen runelord to replace them and continue the fight, unless the PCs can disable this defense during the second adventure in Revenge of the Runelords. Regardless of level, all risen runelords are mythic creatures and are immune to sleep effects.

Lust and Pride

Of the seven sins, lust and pride are unique among the runelords for these sins were only ever represented by a single runelord—and both still live during the events of this Adventure Path. This may change once the events of Revenge of the Runelords come to a conclusion, in which case the sinful foci for lust and pride become potential options for risen runelords of Sorshen or Xanderghul, but during Revenge of the Runelords, no risen runelords of lust or pride can exist.

Risen Runelord Gear

A risen runelord's polearm is an extension of their being and cannot exist without them, vanishing upon their death. This doesn't prevent a risen runelord from claiming, carrying, or using other items, and most higher-level risen runelords keep real magic items that remain behind after their death.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The risen runelord ends one condition affecting them.

action->Beyond Life.name: Beyond Life
action->Beyond Life.description: A risen runelord may drink or eat for pleasure or entertainment, but they need not do so for nourishment and never suffer the effects of thirst or starvation.

action->Mythic Resilience (Will).name: Mythic Resilience (Will)
action->Mythic Resilience (Will).description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Vanishing Death.name: Vanishing Death
action->Vanishing Death.description: When a risen runelord is slain, their body and (if manifested) polearm vanishes as the trapped legacy that was drawn upon to create them is set free, exploding outward in a riot of swirling color. This release of arcane energy hammers the minds of nearby creatures. All creatures adjacent to a risen runelord during their vanishing death must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:27] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 24 hours (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical failure) as fragments of their own memories are temporarily scrambled or hidden. Other objects carried by the risen runelord fall to the ground.

action->Manifest Runelord's Polearm.name: Manifest Runelord's Polearm
action->Manifest Runelord's Polearm.description:
Requirements The risen runelord isn't holding a runelord's polearm

Effect The risen runelord causes their runelord's polearm to appear in one of their hands. The exact appearance of the polearm depends on the type wielded by the runelord in life, but these weapons are purely spiritual constructs that inflict mental damage on a Strike and vanish as soon as the risen runelord releases the weapon or dies.

action->Mythic Power.name: Mythic Power
action->Mythic Power.description: The creature has a pool of 3 Mythic Points, and can spend those Mythic Points for any of the actions it has.

action->Quickened Casting.name: Quickened Casting
action->Quickened Casting.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect If the risen runelord's next action is to cast a cantrip or spell that's 4th-rank or lower, reduce the number of actions to cast it by 1 (minimum 1 action).

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The risen runelord regains an expended spell slot or can use Quickened Casting again.

action->Steady Spellcasting.name: Steady Spellcasting
action->Steady Spellcasting.description: If a reaction would disrupt the risen runelord's spellcasting action, the risen runelord attempts a @Check[flat|dc:15]. On a success, the action isn't disrupted.

Risen Runelord Karzoug.name: Risen Runelord Karzoug
Risen Runelord Karzoug.publicNotes:
Risen runelords are created by a powerful ritual invented by Runelord Xanderghul—a ritual called raise runelord. All risen runelords are at least level 11 creatures. Once created, a risen runelord has no capacity to become more powerful, as they are manifestations of their legacy at a specific point in time (although given enough time and resources, a risen runelord could potentially find a way to overcome this limitation on self-improvement).

A risen runelord has a modicum of free will, but as long as the one who created them via raise runelord lives, they're bound to their creator's desires. A risen runelord ordered to undertake obviously self-destructive actions might, at the GM's discretion, resist the command and could potentially even break free of their creator's control.

Since raise runelord draws upon a runelord's legacy as it exists within the Dreamlands, no risen runelord can ever sleep or dream. Xanderghul can use a risen runelord in a special way: he can use any risen runelord (including ones he didn't create) as a spare body. If he's slain, his soul can instantly jump to the closest risen runelord to replace them and continue the fight, unless the PCs can disable this defense during the second adventure in Revenge of the Runelords. Regardless of level, all risen runelords are mythic creatures and are immune to sleep effects.

Lust and Pride

Of the seven sins, lust and pride are unique among the runelords for these sins were only ever represented by a single runelord—and both still live during the events of this Adventure Path. This may change once the events of Revenge of the Runelords come to a conclusion, in which case the sinful foci for lust and pride become potential options for risen runelords of Sorshen or Xanderghul, but during Revenge of the Runelords, no risen runelords of lust or pride can exist.

Risen Runelord Gear

A risen runelord's polearm is an extension of their being and cannot exist without them, vanishing upon their death. This doesn't prevent a risen runelord from claiming, carrying, or using other items, and most higher-level risen runelords keep real magic items that remain behind after their death.

action->Beyond Life.name: Beyond Life

Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Vanishing Death.description:

Other objects carried by the risen runelord fall to the ground.

action->Chromatic Aegis.description:

Effect Karzoug uses his dying breath to destroy Aethusa's prison and wrap himself in the remnants of its magical energy. While the risen runelord no longer takes part in this Adventure Path, he might, at your discretion, rise again in a future campaign of your design.
