Rune Sentries.name: Rune Sentries
Rune Sentries.descriptionHazard: Arcs of lightning arc flash from the eyes of the floating sentries.
Rune Sentries.disable: @Check[arcana|dc:45] (legendary) to turn the lightning back against the sentry, causing the head to plummet, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (9th rank; counteract DC 36) to counteract the magic that empowers the sentry, causing it to plummet. Each sentry must be counteracted or destroyed separately.
Rune Sentries.routine: (6 actions) Each Rune Sentry grants the hazard 1 action; a Rune Sentry that's plummeted or been disabled or destroyed reduces the hazard's available actions by 1. On the hazard's turn, all active Rune Sentries spend their action to use Lightning Arc.

action->Entry Denied.name: Entry Denied
action->Entry Denied.description:
Trigger The PCs fail the Trial of Runes

Effect Each sentry whose question the PCs answered correctly crashes to the ground. A creature directly below a head when it falls takes @Damage[(6d12+37)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:42|basic] save). The 10-foot area beneath the head becomes difficult terrain. The hazard then rolls initiative.

action->Lightning Arc.name: Lightning Arc
action->Lightning Arc.description: (electricity) One creature (other than the peacock phoenix) within 60 feet of the sentry takes @Damage[(3d12+19)[electricity]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:42|basic] save). A target wearing metal armor or made of metal takes a –1 circumstance penalty to its save; if damaged, they are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 1 round. A creature may only be targeted once by a lightning arc each round—any lightning arcs that go unused as a result of there not being enough targets instead restore 20 HP each to the peacock phoenix.

weapon->Xanderghul's Flawless Hammer.name: Xanderghul's Flawless Hammer
weapon->Xanderghul's Flawless Hammer.description: A bec de corbin is a spiked polearm that uses a hammer head to help balance the spike. The hammer portion can be used as a secondary striking surface, while the spike or fluke is specially designed to punch through armor and shields.

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Xanderghul ends one condition affecting him.

action->Air of Delusion.name: Air of Delusion
action->Air of Delusion.description: 15 feet. False visions and strange shadows dance through the area, obscuring the truth for only Xanderghul to know. A creature that first enters the area must attempt a @Check[will|dc:46] save. On a failure, it's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to Xanderghul whenever it's in the area. On a critical success, the creature is temporarily immune to air of delusion for 1 minute.

action->Anything You Can Do.name: Anything You Can Do
action->Anything You Can Do.description:
Trigger A creature Xanderghul is imitating with illusory disguise takes a single action of any type

Effect If the triggering action is a move action, Xanderghul can use the same distance and method to move himself. If the triggering action is a Strike, Xanderghul can attempt a Strike against any foe in reach with his hammer. If the triggering action was any other type of action, Xanderghul mimics that action via a reflexive illusion that confuses onlookers; Anything You Can Do gains the mental and visual traits, and all observers save the duplicated foe become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to Xanderghul until the end of his next turn.

action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and.name: Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and Will)
action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and.description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->Sin Counterspell.name: Sin Counterspell
action->Sin Counterspell.description:
Trigger A creature within 30 feet casts a spell that creates or changes physical things

Effect Xanderghul attempts to counteract the triggering spell with a [[/r 1d20+42 #Counteract]]{+42} counteract modifier and a counteract rank of 10.

action->Undying Myth.name: Undying Myth
action->Undying Myth.description:
Cost all Xanderghul's Mythic Points

Effect When Xanderghul would die, as long as he has at least 1 Mythic Point, he immediately expends all remaining Mythic Points he has, remains standing and conscious, and recovers 50% of his maximum Hit Points.

action->Ego Boost.name: Ego Boost
action->Ego Boost.description: When a creature fails to disbelieve one of Xanderghul's illusions, he becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} for 1 round and can use the extra action to Stride or Stride.

action->Quickened Casting.name: Quickened Casting
action->Quickened Casting.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect If Xanderghul's next action is to cast a cantrip or spell that is 8th rank or lower, reduce the number of actions to cast it by 1 (minimum 1 action).

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect Xanderghul regains a previously cast spell.

action->Reroll.name: Reroll
action->Reroll.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Trigger Xanderghul fails a check

Effect Xanderghul rerolls the check.

action->Shuffle the Deck.name: Shuffle the Deck
action->Shuffle the Deck.description:
Trigger Xanderghul casts illusory disguise to imitate the appearance of a creature he is adjacent to

Effect Xanderghul and the creature appear to Step several times, exchanging spaces. The target creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:49] save with the following results.

Critical Success The targeted creature may choose which square they Step into, and no other creature is tricked.

Success Xanderghul chooses which square the creature Steps into (which must be a legal space for the creature to occupy, must be able to bear its weight, and cannot be difficult or hazardous terrain), but no other creature is tricked.

Failure As success (but the new space Xanderghul has the target Step into can be difficult or hazardous terrain), but other creatures lose track of who is who. They are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to Xanderghul for 1 round. The next time someone targets either the illusory PC (who is Xanderghul) or the real PC must randomly determine which of the two figures they target.

Critical Failure As failure, but Xanderghul can cause the PC to Step into an area incapable of holding their weight (such as into the swirling mists of Jandelay), and all attempts to target either are randomly determined until the start of Xanderghul's next turn.

action->Sovereign of the False.name: Sovereign of the False
action->Sovereign of the False.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect Xanderghul Sustains one spell with the illusion trait.

action->Vision of Loss.name: Vision of Loss
action->Vision of Loss.description: The first time in a round that Xanderghul hits a creature with his waking dreams Strike, their mind is clouded by illusory hallucinations and waking dreams of all their triumphs not only being revealed to be failures in the end, but with the conviction that had Xanderghul attempted the same, it would've prevailed. The target must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:49] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 1 round (or stupefied 2 with an unlimited duration on a critical failure).

Runic Warmaw.name: Runic Warmaw
Runic Warmaw.publicNotes:
Rune giants have specialized talents and magical abilities to command other giants, yet giants are far from the only creatures they favor when it comes to guardians. The first runic warmaws were created by Runelord Alaznist in –5780, not long after she perfected the fleshwarping techniques she learned from the qlippoth lord Yamasoth, in response to her rune giants' repeated requests for some form of powerful guardian they could deploy against her enemies on the field of battle. In the following years, as with sinspawn and other fleshwarp creations, other runelords capitalized upon these methods to create runic warmaws as well.

A runic warmaw looks somewhat like an immense, elephant-sized hound, yet with horselike heads that have large, toothy jaws well suited to rending flesh. Strange patterns of shifting red runes appear on their black-furred bodies—runes containing latent sources of magic that rune giants can use to access some of a runic warmaw's magical powers.

Specialized Warmaws

The runic warmaw presented here has been specially bred by rune giants to foster magical powers that serve well in combat, but others with a focus on different types of magical tactics, such as research, defense, or travel, exist. These warmaws have differently themed innate spells—replace the three combat-associated spells listed in the stat block as appropriate for the warmaw's theme you desire for the encounter you're building.

action->Echo Arcana.name: Echo Arcana
action->Echo Arcana.description:
Trigger A rune giant within 30 feet casts one of the warmaw's innate spells by reading their shared runes

Effect The runic warmaw makes a jaws Strike.

action->Rune Flare.name: Rune Flare
action->Rune Flare.description:
Trigger The runic warmaw is targeted by an arcane spell or effect

Effect The runes etched across the runic warmaw's body burst to life with a sudden flow of energy. The runic warmaw becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} for 1 round and can use the additional action only to Stride or Strike.

action->Howl of Ash and Ember.name: Howl of Ash and Ember
action->Howl of Ash and Ember.description: The runic warmaw exhales a surge of foul soot and flame, dealing @Damage[15d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:cone|distance:60] (@Check[reflex|dc:37|basic] save). A creature that fails the save is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure). The runic warmaw can't use Howl of Ash and Ember again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Howl of Ash and Ember]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Invigorating Bite.name: Invigorating Bite
action->Invigorating Bite.description: When a runic warmaw critically hits a target with a jaws Strike, they regain 30 Hit Points and, at the start of their next turn, gain an additional reaction during that turn.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The runic warmaw's Strikes deal an additional 3d6 precision damage to creatures within the reach of at least two of the runic warmaw's allies.

action->Share Runes.name: Share Runes
action->Share Runes.description: When a runic warmaw is within 60 feet of a rune giant, that rune giant can cast any of the runic warmaw's innate spells during the rune giant's turn—these spells use the rune giant's DCs but are depleted from the warmaw's daily uses. The rune giant is the point of origin and makes all the decisions about the spell's targets.

Shattered Runewell of Pride.name: Shattered Runewell of Pride
Shattered Runewell of Pride.descriptionHazard: Plumes of magenta and violet light and vapor shift and writhe out of a hole in reality surrounded by the fragments of a runewell suspended mid-explosion.
Shattered Runewell of Pride.disable: @Check[arcana|dc:37] (master) or @Check[occultism|dc:40] (master) to redirect the magic back in on itself and cancel out the danger, or @Check[crafting|dc:40] (legendary) to reposition runewell fragments so they're not dangerous; three total successes are required to disable the shattered runewell
Shattered Runewell of Pride.routine: (3 actions) When the shattered runewell takes its first action, a towering, 30-foot-tall image of Runelord Xanderghul formed from scintillating magenta and violet light and fire looms up from the runewell. On each of the hazard's three actions, this manifestation of Runelord Xanderghul scowls down at the PCs, and tendrils of strangely colored fire lash out of the runewell, each targeting a different PC in the area. The effects of these tendrils vary according to their color; these ranged Strikes can target anyone in the Eye of Arrogance and accrue multiple attack penalties normally.
Shattered Runewell of Pride.stealth: (expert) to realize that the shattered runewell is dangerous; noticing the hazard has a DC of 0

action->Frightful Shriek.name: Frightful Shriek
action->Frightful Shriek.description:
Trigger Intruders enter the Eye of Arrogance

Effect All of the illusory peacocks in the demiplane emit loud shrieks of anger. All intruders to the Eye of Arrogance must attempt a @Check[will|dc:37] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} on a critical failure). The shattered runewell then rolls initiative.

strike-melee->Iridescent Fire.name: Iridescent Fire
strike-melee->Iridescent Fire.description: plus the struck creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round if they fail a @Check[will|dc:37] save

Silent Devotee.name: Silent Devotee
Silent Devotee.publicNotes:
When the runelords first created the Emerald Chambers, an order of martial spellcasters was established to protect Xin's tomb. Known as the Silent Devotees, members of this order cut out their own eyes and tongues in a gesture intended both to prove their devotion and to ensure that knowledge of the Emerald Chambers would never spread beyond the order. After an initial surge of volunteers, interest in the order waned once the duplicitous nature of the runelords (and rumors of their involvement in Xin's assassination) came to light. Today, only a few dozen silent devotees remain.

The devotees expanded the scope of their mission after the runelords claimed portions of the Emerald Chambers for their personal use. These devotees fitted their empty eye sockets with emeralds magically imbued with the site plans for the Chambers, allowing them to patrol the extradimensional space in its entirety. Combined with the raw magic flowing through the Chambers, the emeralds turned the skin of the devotees a pallid green but also gifted them with a sort of immortality, such that the remaining devotees seem immune to the ravages of time. Today, the Silent Devotees are something more than the humans they once were.

Xin-Hndoros

The most devoted member of the Silent Devotees was surely Xin-Undoros, a loyal champion of Xin and one of the order's first volunteers. Though he predicted Earthfall, Xin-Undoros failed to warn the runelords of the catastrophe, blaming them for the death of his beloved emperor. As punishment for this treachery, Xin-Undoros became a graveknight shortly after the end came. While this transformation returned Xin-Undoros's ability to speak, he still refuses to do so, regarding such an act as a violation of his eternal oath.
Silent Devotee.allSavesBonus: +2 status to all saves vs. auditory
Silent Devotee.languagesDetails: can't speak any language, Telepathy 100 feet

action->Untouched by Time.name: Untouched by Time
action->Untouched by Time.description: Though not undead, silent devotees don't age as most mortal creatures do. They don't eat, drink, sleep, or breathe.

action->+2 Status to All Saves Vs. Audit.name: +2 Status to All Saves Vs. Auditory

action->Pall of Silence.name: Pall of Silence
action->Pall of Silence.description: 10 feet. The silent devotee is surrounded by an aura that suppresses sound, granting the silent devotee resistance to sonic energy and a bonus to all saves against auditory effects. Creatures within the aura can't use sonic attacks, use auditory actions, or Cast a Spell without the subtle trait.

action->Cruel Sneak Attack.name: Cruel Sneak Attack
action->Cruel Sneak Attack.description: A silent devotee's Strikes deal and additional 2d6 precision damage to creatures that are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} or are taking persistent bleed damage.

action->Quieting Rune.name: Quieting Rune
action->Quieting Rune.description: The silent devotee marks a creature within 60 feet they can see with a rune of magical silence. The creature must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:34] saving throw or be affected as if by a 7th-rank silence spell. The rune lasts for 1 minute or until the devotee dies. A creature can be marked with only one Quieting Rune at a time. If the devotee uses this ability again, any previous Quieting Rune they've created ends.

action->Transdimensional Step.name: Transdimensional Step
action->Transdimensional Step.description: The silent devotee teleports to an unoccupied space within 30 feet.

Slothful Stairs.name: Slothful Stairs
Slothful Stairs.descriptionHazard: A supernatural exhaustion fills creatures who climb the stairs.
Slothful Stairs.disable: @Check[athletics|dc:45] (legendary) to wedge crumbling stones into cracks to jam the collapsing stairs, @Check[thievery|dc:48] (master) to deface the hidden magical runes that power the trap; or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (9th rank, counteract DC 36) to counteract a rune; three total successes are required to disable the trap
Slothful Stairs.reset: The trap continues taking Leaden Limbs actions (and the void at the bottom of the stairwell remains open) for as long as creatures remain in the area. Once no creatures remain, the stairwell rebuilds itself, the void closes, and the trap resets.
Slothful Stairs.routine: (2 actions) The haunt uses Leaden Limbs once, then Crumbling Stairs once.

action->Collapse.name: Collapse
action->Collapse.description:
Trigger A creature inspects the wall at the top of the stairs or begins to descend the stairs after reaching the top

Effect The floor at the bottom of the stairwell disappears, revealing a seemingly bottomless pit. Meanwhile, the stairwell begins to collapse, starting from the top and working its way down. Any PC standing on the lower few steps falls into the pit unless they Grab the Edge with a successful @Check[reflex|dc:40] save. The trap then rolls initiative.

action->Leaden Limbs.name: Leaden Limbs
action->Leaden Limbs.description:
The trap drains vigor from creatures in the stairwell, making their limbs feel as heavy as lead. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] saving throw with the following results.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} until the end of their next turn.

Failure The creature's clumsy condition value increases by 1, to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 4}. The creature is slowed 1 as long as they remain clumsy. The clumsy condition ends as soon as the creature exits the stairwell.

Critical Failure As failure, but the value increases by 2, and the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2}.

action->Crumbling Stairs.name: Crumbling Stairs
action->Crumbling Stairs.description:
A stretch of stairs crumbles, dropping into the void at the bottom of the stairwell. The first time the trap takes this action, the upper third of the stairwell collapses. The second time, the middle third collapses. The third time, the entire stairwell collapses. A creature on a collapsing section of stairs can try to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab an Edge} with a @Check[reflex|dc:40] save to avoid falling into the void. Flying creatures avoid the fall automatically but might tumble into the void anyway if their slowed condition prevents them from taking the Fly action on their turn.

Though it appears to stretch forever, the void at the bottom of the stairwell functions as a portal to the Crypt of Sloth. Creatures who plummet into the void experience a fall that seems to take hours, but are eventually deposited in the middle of area B10, taking @Damage[80[bludgeoning]] damage from the fall.

Supervolcanic Eruption.name: Supervolcanic Eruption
Supervolcanic Eruption.descriptionHazard:
Volcanic eruptions are dramatic events in which magma erupts from a planet's mantle onto its surface. They're often preceded by earthquakes and the opening of fissures in the ground that vent toxic gases. These initial signs can occur months or even years in advance, making it difficult to predict the eruption's timing. While the intensity, features, and progression of eruptions vary, this hazard represents the most dangerous variety of eruption, one that can swiftly overtake cities with rapid tides of superheated gas and rock and spew out enough ash to affect the climate for years. When these sorts of eruptions are also supervolcanos, eruptions with the highest degree of explosive force, they cause unparalleled transformation to the landscape and alter climate on a planetary scale.

If you're looking for something more supernatural, it's a relatively simple change to adjust the energy damage caused by a supervolcano's pyroclastic flow to something else—for example, a cloud of ghosts erupting from a long-lost city might inflict mental, spirit, or void damage instead of the fire or electricity damage a normal pyroclastic flow brings. Just be sure to give the new event a suitable description that matches the new type of damage!
Supervolcanic Eruption.disable: @Check[Mountain Lore|dc:42] (master), @Check[survival|dc:45] (master), or @Check[nature|dc:48] (legendary) to determine evacuation paths, @Check[medicine|dc:45] (master) to safely treat and relocate people poisoned by toxic gases in the preceding days, @Check[athletics|dc:48] (master) to relocate people and essential supplies, or @Check[crafting|dc:48] (legendary) to create filtration systems and barricades capable of withstanding a pyroclastic flow
Supervolcanic Eruption.routine:
(24 hours) When the hazard begins, toxic gas vents open throughout the affected region, followed by clouds of ash. As the eruption column collapses, material rushes forth from the volcano in a pyroclastic flow, which is followed by a dense ash cloud that persists for several minutes. Ash and toxic gas persist for up to 24 hours.

Ash limits visibility like a thick fog, deals @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage per minute, and creates difficult terrain as it collects on the ground. The ash also generates bolts of ash lightning. Once per minute, one unprepared PC takes @Damage[3d12[electricity]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:46|basic] save). Pockets of dense ash are particularly dangerous. Unprepared creatures in areas of dense ash must hold their breath or begin to suffocate.

When the pyroclastic flow first hits a region, creatures in its path must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:43] save with the following results (prepared creatures increase their roll by one degree of success).

Critical Success The creature avoids most of the pyroclastic flow, but still takes @Damage[3d6[fire]] damage and treats all movement in the area as greater difficult terrain for the next 10 minutes.

Success The creature takes @Damage[3d6[bludgeoning]] damage and @Damage[3d6[fire]] damage, and is buried in ash and debris. While buried, they can't breathe and take @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage each round at the start of their turn until they succeed at a DC 40 check to Escape, in addition to the normal @Damage[1d6[bludgeoning]] damage each minute for being buried.

Failure As success, but @Damage[6d6[bludgeoning]] damage and @Damage[6d6[fire]] damage, and [[/act escape dc=42]].

Critical Failure As success, but @Damage[12d6[bludgeoning]] damage and @Damage[12d6[fire]] damage, and [[/act escape dc=46]].
Supervolcanic Eruption.stealth: @Check[Mountain Lore|dc:40] (master), @Check[survival|dc:42] (master), or @Check[nature|dc:45] (legendary) to predict the eruption's arrival

The Ashen Man.name: The Ashen Man
The Ashen Man.publicNotes:
In the Dimension of Time, creatures clad in tattered robes float between encapsulated bubbles of still, captured moments, untethered to any other place, unspeaking and unseeing. The few mortals to meet these enigmatic, faceless creatures have never known them to identify by any name other than the ancient ones, seemingly holding no identity (or no identity they wish to share) beyond their relationship with time.

The ancients profess to have always existed in the Dimension of Time, and for time to have always existed in the Great Beyond. Most reside in Stethelos, the storied city at the center of time, though they're also found wandering the Void, crossing the strangest corners of the Maelstrom where it lies between other planes, and occasionally, venturing into dark corners of the Universe. They serve at the will of Tawil at'Umr, the All in One and the One in All, an avatar of Yog-Sothoth lurking deep within time as Stethelos's caretaker. Though the ancient ones resemble their master in stature and attire, and though none would describe Tawil at'Umr as anything other than ancient in origin, most scholars consider "ancient one" a classification of its own separate from that of Great Old One, and Tawil at'Umr is definitively counted among the Great Old Ones by all who know it.

Where Yog-Sothoth is an embodiment of all space and time, an entity who concerns himself with guarding cosmic secrets, the ancient ones are philosophers and mystics seeking ever more enlightenment. They search, have searched, and will search across time indefinitely and, having found entropy and disorder, conclude this to be the Great Beyond's ultimate purpose. When a new creature dawns, it's pristine and whole—perfectly ordered—for but a single moment before it can be eroded by Pharasma's poison, accumulating decay, change, and chaos, until finally it reaches its ending, when time leaves a twilight creature broken and gone. Law and chaos, the ancient ones believe, aren't opposing or even separate forces, but a single expression of reality viewed from two angles, different from each other only in time.

How Old is Time?

Lying in parallel with the Great Beyond with a presence felt on nearly every plane, from the Inner Sphere to the Outer Rifts, the Dimension of Time holds too many secrets for a reality so seemingly omnipresent. Can a world truly be said to begin before time is there to start? Scholars say Pharasma is the oldest being in the Great Beyond, a survivor of some previous multiverse's collapse, but does the Lady of Graves predate time, or did she bring the Dimension of Time with her so history could begin everything anew?

Into the Dimension of Time

The Dimension of Time is one of the most difficult and complex realms in the Great Beyond to travel to, with restrictions on its access limiting all but the most powerful of planar travelers from visiting it. At the GM's discretion, though, items looted from an ancient one, or even just fragments torn from their robes, could function as the planar key needed to allow a PC to use interplanar teleport to access the Dimension of Time.

weapon->Doomsday Scepter.name: Doomsday Scepter
weapon->Doomsday Scepter.description: While many greatclubs are intricately carved, others are little more than a sturdy tree branch. These massive clubs are too heavy to wield with only one hand.

action->Doomsday Scepter.name: Doomsday Scepter
action->Doomsday Scepter.description: When the Ashen Man turns his attention to a world, a projection of that planet manifests among the branches of the doomsday scepter he carries. He can wield this device in combat as a greatclub. If he releases his grip on the doomsday scepter or it's disarmed, it vanishes, after which the Ashen Man can cause it to appear in his hand again as a free action with the concentrate trait during his turn.

action->Entropy Sense.name: Entropy Sense
action->Entropy Sense.description: The ancient one can predict the presence of a creature through supernatural insight into chaotic probabilities and chance and builds a perception of reality from this information, allowing them to "see" as a precise sense in the listed range. Invisible creatures are visible to them, but veil of privacy prevents a creature from being detected via entropy sense automatically (without a counteract check).

action->Remove a Condition.name: Remove a Condition
action->Remove a Condition.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The Ashen Man ends one condition affecting him.

action->Cohesion Vulnerability.name: Cohesion Vulnerability
action->Cohesion Vulnerability.description: The Ashen Man is repulsed by an orderly reality. Whenever the Ashen Man sees a creature that was injured restored to its full Hit Points, he becomes obsessed with correcting the defiance of entropy. He takes @Damage[8d6[mental]] damage and can't use actions with the concentrate trait until he's dealt damage to that creature that reduces their Hit Point total from its maximum value.

action->Feast on Destruction.name: Feast on Destruction
action->Feast on Destruction.description: 120 feet. Wait long enough and reality always proves that all things begin so they can end. The Ashen Man is empowered whenever this belief is vindicated. When a creature in the aura gains the dying condition or increases its dying value, the Ashen Man becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} 1 for 1 round. He can use the extra action only to Stride or Strike.

action->Multiple Reactions.name: Multiple Reactions
action->Multiple Reactions.description: The Ashen Man's untethered relationship with time gives him an additional reaction each round, though he still can't use more than one reaction on the same triggering action.

action->Mutually Assured.name: Mutually Assured
action->Mutually Assured.description:
Trigger A creature within 10 feet deals damage to the Ashen Man

Effect Reality hurtles toward destruction. The Ashen Man makes a wretched claw Strike against the triggering creature.

action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and.name: Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and Will)
action->Mythic Resilience (Fortitude and.description: The creature treats its saving throws with the associated save as one degree of success better than it rolled. This is not cumulative with other effects that change their degree of success, like the incapacitation trait (except for rolling a natural 1 or 20). Each time the monster gains mythic resilience, choose one save. The ability should apply to the creature's highest saves first.

action->No Breath.name: No Breath
action->No Breath.description: An ancient one doesn't breathe and is immune to effects that require breathing (such as inhaled poisons).

action->Otherworldly Mind.name: Otherworldly Mind
action->Otherworldly Mind.description: Whenever a creature targets the ancient one with a mental effect, that creature takes @Damage[8d8[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:43|basic] save). On a critical failure, the creature also becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->The Connection Cuts Both Ways.name: The Connection Cuts Both Ways
action->The Connection Cuts Both Ways.description: Creatures the ancient one affected with a mental effect or communicated with telepathically within the last round can hijack the ancient one's telepathic connection; they automatically ignore the ancient one's immunity to auditory, emotion, and visual effects until the end of their current turn. They can additionally spend 1 Mythic Point as a free action to reach through the connection to manipulate the ancient one's mind, ignoring the ancient one's mythic resilience on Will saving throws.

action->Undying Myth.name: Undying Myth
action->Undying Myth.description:
Cost all of the Ancient One's Mythic Points

Trigger The Ashen Man would die and has at least 1 Mythic Point

Effect The Ashen Man remains standing and conscious, and recovers 50% of his maximum Hit Points.

action->Unified Timeline.name: Unified Timeline
action->Unified Timeline.description:
Trigger A creature ends its movement within 10 feet of the ancient one

Effect Ancient ones exist spread out across infinite times and places simultaneously and can shift themselves through their catalog of potentialities. The ancient one teleports themself and the triggering creature into empty squares within 10 feet of their respective positions, though the triggering creature can't be moved into hazardous terrain or to a place it can't stand. An unwilling creature can resist the teleportation with a successful @Check[will|dc:46] save.

action->Curse of Destiny.name: Curse of Destiny
action->Curse of Destiny.description: When the Ashen Man hits a creature with a doomsday scepter Strike, he inflicts the cursed destiny held in trust for all creatures who live: a promise of future death. The target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:46] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2}. On a critical failure, the target additionally becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1} or increases its current doomed value by 1.

action->Dismantle All Life.name: Dismantle All Life
action->Dismantle All Life.description: Time and entropy end all things, even the undead. When the ancient one's Strikes hit a creature with void healing, they deal vitality damage instead of void damage. The ancient one can't use their Strikes to restore Hit Points to living or undead creatures.

action->Recharge.name: Recharge
action->Recharge.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Effect The Ashen Man regains an expended spell.

action->Reroll.name: Reroll
action->Reroll.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Trigger The Ashen Man fails a check

Effect The Ashen Man rerolls the check.

action->Slither Between Realities.name: Slither Between Realities
action->Slither Between Realities.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger The Ashen Man begins or ends his turn

Effect The Great Beyond loses track of the Ashen Man, and he slips between reality's cracks, instantly transporting himself and any items he's wearing and holding from his current space to an unoccupied space within 100 feet that he can see.

action->Unravel Reality.name: Unravel Reality
action->Unravel Reality.description: The Ashen Man holds aloft his doomsday scepter then swings it violently downward as he rips the quintessence of the planes apart in a @Template[type:line|distance:60], creating difficult terrain and dealing @Damage[24d6[spirit]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature in the area (@Check[fortitude|dc:46|basic] save). The Ashen Man can't Unravel Reality again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Unravel Reality]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Visions of the Forever.name: Visions of the Forever
action->Visions of the Forever.description:
Cost 1 Mythic Point

Frequency once per round

Effect The Ashen Man shrinks the distance separating all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:120], brushing up against their minds and granting them vivid, waking dreams. All who share the hallucination experience entire millennia in an instant, rushed into a bleak future where they alone are stranded as the last living person in a destroyed world of ash and ruin. There, as the sole survivor of an empty reality where even the gods have fallen, they hear the Ashen Man's voice ring through their minds a final time, demanding an explanation that justifies their fate. Each affected creature attempts a @Check[will|dc:46] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and can break the telepathic contact, dismissing the vision.

Success The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round by the unnerving vision.

Failure The creature is filled with dread and compelled to answer the Ashen Man's question, becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and slowed 1 for 1 minute. It can't reduce its frightened value below 1 for as long as it remains slowed.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 4} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2}. In addition, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{Fleeing} for 1 round.

The Gullet.name: The Gullet
The Gullet.descriptionHazard: Images of excessive feasts decorate the walls of the hallway.
The Gullet.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:43] (expert) to jam the hallway so it can't tilt; a character who succeeds at a @Check[acrobatics|dc:46] or @Check[athletics|dc:46] check can balance or sprint the length of the hallway before it has a chance to tilt. Flying creatures and Tiny creatures don't trigger the trap. Creative solutions (such as loading the hallway's western half with an appropriate counterweight) might also disable the trap.
The Gullet.reset: Once the weight in the eastern end of the hallway is removed, the ramp rises back to its original position and the trap immediately resets.
The Gullet.stealth: (master) to notice the hallway is constructed to tilt on a hinge point halfway down its length

action->See-saw.name: See-saw
action->See-saw.description:
Trigger The number of PCs in the eastern half of the hallway equals or exceeds the number in the western half

Effect The eastern side of the hallway floor tilts at a 45-degree angle, its end descending. Any creature standing in this section of the hall must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:43] save to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab an Edge}. On a failure, the creature falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}, tumbles eastward down the length of the ramp, and falls 30 feet into a chamber beneath the hall (area B4b), taking @Damage[(3d12+15)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:43|basic] save). A PC within 10 feet of the hallway's eastern end when it tilts can instead attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:40] save to scramble into area B5. A PC who fails this check instead tumbles and rolls all the way down the steeply sloped ramp before plummeting into area B4b.

action->Tortured Gaze.name: Tortured Gaze
action->Tortured Gaze.description: 30 feet, or 60 feet if the tormented hero is at 170 HP or lower. The psychic agony of the tormented hero spills into the world around them, inflicting murderous hallucinations of being trampled by the Oliphaunt or crushed beneath Spindlehorn. A non-undead creature that ends its turn in the aura must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:37] save or take @Damage[5d8[bludgeoning]] damage and be knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Scream in Agony.name: Scream in Agony
action->Scream in Agony.description: Each creature in the tormented hero's tortured gaze aura takes @Damage[18d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:40|basic] save). A creature that fails is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure). The tormented can't Scream in Agony again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Scream in Agony]]{1d4 rounds} but recharges the ability whenever they take damage from an attacker's critical hit or their own critical failure on a saving throw.

action->Counterspell.name: Counterspell
action->Counterspell.description:
Trigger A creature casts a spell the initiate has prepared

Effect The initiate expends a prepared spell to counter the triggering creature's casting of that same spell. The initiate loses their spell slot as if they had cast the triggering spell. The initiate then attempts to counteract the triggering spell.

action->Bespell Strikes.name: Bespell Strikes
action->Bespell Strikes.description:
Frequency once per turn

Requirements The initiate's most recent action was to cast a non-cantrip spell

Effect The initiate siphons spell energy into their bec de corbin. Until the end of their turn, that weapon deals an extra 1d6 force damage and gains the arcane trait.

Trinity Star.name: Trinity Star
Trinity Star.descriptionHazard: A blazing comet with three tails—one red, one black, and one with rainbow hues—careens throughout the area.
Trinity Star.disable: @Check[athletics|dc:48] (legendary) to grab one of the comet's tails and rip it free; @Check[occultism|dc:45] or @Check[religion|dc:45] (master) to exorcise the divine energy of the red tail (which is infused with Gorum's legacy) or the black tail (infused with the nihilism of Abaddon's Eclipse); @Check[arcana|dc:45] (master) to unweave the magic of the rainbow tail (Xanderghul's mythic power); or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (9th rank; counteract DC 36) to counteract one of the tails. Each tail must be disabled separately to disable the hazard.
Trinity Star.reset:
(1 action) The Trinity Star flies at a speed of 60 feet, moving through the spaces of as many creatures as possible. Each creature the Trinity Star moves through must make a @Check[reflex|dc:42] save with the following results.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[6d6[force]] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[11d6[force]] damage and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[22d6[force]] damage, is knocked prone, and if the creature is mythic, they lose 1 Mythic Point. If the Trinity Star has lost any of its tails, it regrows one of them (chosen at random if it's lost two tails).

action->Starform.name: Starform
action->Starform.description:
Trigger Dream Aethusa has been dead for 10 minutes

Effect Dream Aethusa's body is consumed with mythic energy, transforming into a comet with three blazing tails. All creatures within 120 feet must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save to resist becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 minute (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} permanently on a critical failure). The hazard then rolls initiative.

Unspeakable Impressions.name: Unspeakable Impressions
Unspeakable Impressions.descriptionHazard: A trail of over-sized footprints crosses the path, markings of the apparently recent passage of a dangerous and mind-shattering entity whose stride is enough to be mistaken for depressions in the natural terrain, and promising destruction to those compelled to follow the tracks.
Unspeakable Impressions.disable: @Check[deception|dc:46] (master) to distract those (including yourself) compelled to follow footprints, or @Check[survival|dc:43] (legendary) to quickly obscure the trail
Unspeakable Impressions.reset: The unspeakable impressions fade once they are triggered, but reform somewhere else in the vicinity 24 hours later unless they are successfully disabled.

action->Beckoning Trail.name: Beckoning Trail
action->Beckoning Trail.description:
Trigger A creature crosses over the footprints' trail

Effect The triggering creature suddenly realizes the nature of the immense trail they just stepped into and feels a compulsion to follow the trail to their destination; the triggering creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:35] save with the following results.

Critical Success The creature Strides once down the trail before coming to their senses—this movement does not put the creature in any peril or danger.

Success The creature takes its three actions to Stride down the trail. While this movement doesn't put the creature in any direct peril, when they end the movement, they're overwhelmed with the knowledge that had they gone further, something horrible would have happened; the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 1 hour by the close call.

Failure As success, but the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1} and also stupefied 1 for 24 hours.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}. In addition, at the end of the three Strides, the creature vanishes from view, instantly teleporting to some dangerous area or hidden prison. This might be a nearby location that the creature's allies can discover and rescue them from, or it may be somewhere further away that will require more effort to reach before the victim can be rescued.

Vesinra.name: Vesinra
Vesinra.publicNotes:
The brilliant and powerful lamia matriarchs possess boundless ambition, always seeking to bring more people and territory into the clutches of their kind. Consequently, they become rulers of other lamia. For all their cruelty toward other creatures, they're fierce protectors of other lamia, and consequently, they quickly come to rule cults or warbands. Regardless of the lamia's gender, these ascended lamias are always known as matriarchs. A lamia matriarch is set apart from their kindred by the occult power they pursue, and some have even had grand designs to break the animalistic curse that transformed them. However, every attempt so far has led to the matriarch's fall.

Lamias are bloodthirsty victims of an ancient curse for which they blame the gods. Most lamias are humanoid from the waist up but have the lower bodies of serpents. Sinister magic comes naturally to a lamia, and they prefer the use of illusions to deceive prey for later consumption, or simply to torture.
Vesinra.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The lamia matriarch can take on the appearance of a Medium humanoid. This doesn't change their Speed or their attack and damage modifiers with their Strikes, but it does prevent them from using their cursed touch. Each lamia matriarch has a fixed humanoid form that resembles their upper torso when in their true form. This is the only humanoid form they can adopt using this ability.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Falchion Swipe.name: Falchion Swipe
action->Falchion Swipe.description: Vesinra makes a falchion attack against each enemy within reach. Each attack counts toward her multiple attack penalty, but the penalty does not increase until after all the attacks. The first enemy she damages is subject to Vesinra's Caress.

action->Vesinra's Caress.name: Vesinra's Caress
action->Vesinra's Caress.description: Vesinra touches a creature, who must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:30] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2}. If the target fails additional saves against this ability, the condition value increases by 2 (to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 4}). This condition value decreases by 1 every 24 hours.

Vogorond.name: Vogorond
Vogorond.publicNotes:
Vogoronds are the remains of destroyed worlds imbued with the beliefs, hopes, and memories of that world's people. Their physical bodies often take the shape of monuments held dear by their worlds' former inhabitants, such as a statue of a beloved monarch. Vogoronds are intelligent and often seek to see their destroyed worlds reborn. Because their consciousnesses are formed from millions or even billions of individuals, however, they rarely possess the reasoning needed to pursue their desires to an end.

Reasoning With the Ruined Past

While a vogorond's memories aren't flawless, it knows more about its former world than any scholar could ever hope to learn. Often, a vogorond is the only remaining source of knowledge about the land it once inhabited. Theoretically, heroes from a world on the brink of destruction could travel forward in time to speak with a vogorond and learn what must be done to avert the apocalypse—an act which, paradoxically, would prevent the vogorond from being created in the first place.
Vogorond.languagesDetails: Plus one or more dead languages spoken on their home world

action->Dreams of the Past.name: Dreams of the Past
action->Dreams of the Past.description: When a sleeping or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} creature wakes up within 20 feet of a vogorond, its memories are overwritten by those of an inhabitant of the vogorond's home world. The target is affected by a 9th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5BbU1V6wGSGbrmRD]{Never Mind} spell (@Check[will|dc:40] save).

action->Ruinous Aura.name: Ruinous Aura
action->Ruinous Aura.description: 10 feet. The air surrounding the vogorond is filled with floating rubble and debris. This area is difficult terrain for creatures other than the vogorond. Each time the vogorond is subjected to a critical hit while their aura is active, the aura's radius increases by 10 feet. If the vogorond's ruinous aura would ever extend to more than 30 feet, the vogorond crumbles apart and is destroyed.

action->Activate Aura.name: Activate Aura
action->Activate Aura.description: The vogorond's ruinous aura activates, extending to a range of 10 feet, and the vogorond can Fly once. The vogorond can Activate Aura as a free action when they roll initiative.

action->Debris Storm.name: Debris Storm
action->Debris Storm.description: Each enemy in the vogorond's ruinous aura takes @Damage[8d6[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic] save).

action->Launch Rubble.name: Launch Rubble
action->Launch Rubble.description:
Requirements The vogorond's ruinous aura is active

Effect The vogorond launches a piece of rubble up to 100 feet. Upon impact, the rubble explodes in a @Template[type:burst|distance:20]. Any creatures in the area take @Damage[15d8[bludgeoning]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:40|basic] save). The radius of the vogorond's aura then decreases by 10 feet. The vogorond can't Launch Rubble again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Launch Rubble]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Monument.name: Monument
action->Monument.description: The vogorond deactivates their ruinous aura. Until the next time they act, the vogorond appears to be an inanimate statue, altar, or fragment of architecture. They have an automatic result of 45 on Deception checks and DCs to pass as such an object.

action->Vogorond Lore.name: Vogorond Lore
action->Vogorond Lore.description: A vogorond serves as a repository of the memories of the inhabitants of their home world. This gives them the Vogorond Lore skill, which they use when casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.ZYoC630tNGutgbE0]{Hypercognition} and sifting through the combined memories of their countless shattered minds.

Watcher.name: Watcher
Watcher.publicNotes:
Watchers lurk in the shadows of the Universe, witnessing as history unfolds around them across space and time. They come to worlds on the brink of destruction, recording these worlds' fates and cataloguing apocalyptic events for eternal enshrinement in their massive archives of Jandelay. Watchers usually perform this work unseen, slipping into the background of a plane so they can set their strange beacons undisturbed and secretly place creatures into stasis for transport back to their archives.

Though they concern themselves with calamities and apocalyptic events, the watchers have no desire to see a world end before its time. They're attracted to the actions of mortal heroes who defy fate and work to avert disasters, and they only rarely intervene to preserve an appointed apocalypse from being stalled by these heroes, often content to witness and record the curious heroics.

When faced with unusual news or threats to Jandelay, watchers congregate into small councils to discuss and consider. These councils typically number no more than five watchers, with one watcher designated as the council's observer, recording and remembering the meetings. Watcher councils are patient and deliberate, slow to reach any decisions, but once they reach a conclusion, there's always a unanimous consensus.

Watchers have six long, slick insectile legs and stand approximately 30 feet tall. Small, prehensile filaments hide within their talons, which allow the watchers to achieve an astonishing degree of manual precision.

Many watchers hold an almost religious reverence for the cycle of preservation and destruction that emerges between themselves and the Oliphaunt of Jandelay. This dualistic belief in that which is eternal and that which is lost is commonly interpreted as a faith that deifies both the Oliphaunt and a mysterious First Watcher as demigods of Jandelay. The watchers are often seen alongside the Oliphaunt when it rampages across the Universe, and whether they truly see it as a god, a colleague, or merely a necessary planar phenomenon, the truth of their relationship might simply defy mortal categorization and understanding.

Creation and Destruction

The watchers share Jandelay's fields with the Oliphaunt, herald of the apocalypse, a gargantuan beast that visits worlds on the eve of their annihilation to wreak havoc and destruction. Few scholars can agree if the watchers reach a doomed world first, creating beacons that call the Oliphaunt, or if the Oliphaunt instinctively knows when a world is on the brink of calamity and the watchers follow it as their apocalyptic guide.

Fending Off the Watchers

The Beacons of Jandelay, towers of energy erected by watchers to mark worlds on the eve of their apocalypse, are a terrifying sight for those who recognize their significance. Though the watchers are commonly understood as mere observers and recorders, some scholars theorize the watchers call the Oliphaunt from Jandelay themselves only after erecting their beacons and preparing to record the ensuing calamity. By repelling the watchers and destroying their beacons (which have AC 48, Hardness 40, and 380 HP) or countering the beacons with an effect like dispel magic, these scholars believe doomed worlds can be snatched from the jaws of ruin.

action->Apocalyptic Knowledge.name: Apocalyptic Knowledge
action->Apocalyptic Knowledge.description: A watcher can attempt a Jandelay Lore check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} about any world that has been destroyed or is on the precipice of destruction.

action->Speechless.name: Speechless
action->Speechless.description: A watcher can't speak aloud and must use writing, telepathy, or other methods to communicate.

action->Inconspicuous Mien.name: Inconspicuous Mien
action->Inconspicuous Mien.description: Despite their size, a watcher's role as an uninvolved observer of the Great Beyond causes most creatures to overlook and ignore them. A watcher is always undetected, and a creature must deliberately @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} to perceive them unless it succeeds at a @Check[will|dc:45] saving throw to perceive the watcher (usually as a free action at the start of an encounter). The watcher is automatically perceived by a creature they interact with, such as by attacking the creature or targeting it with a spell or effect.

action->Stabilization Vulnerability.name: Stabilization Vulnerability
action->Stabilization Vulnerability.description: Whenever a watcher's teleportation effect is counteracted as it's being activated, they become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

action->Beacon of Jandelay.name: Beacon of Jandelay
action->Beacon of Jandelay.description: The watcher spends 10 minutes erecting a glowing spire of pale yellow energy, marking an important site destined for an apocalypse for collection and preservation in the Apocalypse Archive. Whenever a watcher uses a teleportation effect to reach a Beacon of Jandelay, they don't need a locus and always arrive on target. A watcher can create a Beacon of Jandelay even while Out of Phase. If the watcher creates a new beacon, any previous Beacon of Jandelay they created vanishes.

action->Mythic Ritualist.name: Mythic Ritualist
action->Mythic Ritualist.description: Although a watcher isn't a mythic creature, when they cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.4ddJSjC9Zz5DX0oG]{Freedom} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2CNqkt2s2IYkVnv6]{Imprisonment}, they attempt Occultism checks at mythic proficiency, and roll those checks twice and take the better of the two results.

action->Out of Phase.name: Out of Phase
action->Out of Phase.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The watcher shifts themself out to desynchronize with reality, allowing them to observe a world without becoming caught in the world's events (including any apocalypses). While Out of Phase, the watcher is invulnerable to all damage and can't be targeted or affected by anything for 1 round, but they can't cast spells, activate items, or use actions that have the attack or manipulate trait. A watcher can Sustain this activity as long as they wish and automatically phases back in at the end of a turn in which they don't do so. A watcher can also Dismiss this activity as free action at the beginning of their turn.

action->Torn from Time.name: Torn from Time
action->Torn from Time.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger The watcher's last action was to damage a creature with their talon Strike

Effect The creature's body grows numb, and it loses control of its muscles, entering a form of temporal hibernation. The creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:45] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is slowed 1 with an unlimited duration and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:45] save at the end of each of its turns. On a failed save, its slowed condition value increases by 1 (or by 2 on a critical failure). A successful save reduces the slowed condition value by 1 (or by 2 on a critical success); the effect ends if this reduces the value to 0. A creature unable to act due to the slowed condition from Torn from Time becomes permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} and enters a state of suspended animation in which they don't age or require food or drink. A creature in this form of stasis remains aware of its surroundings and the passage of time, and if left in this state long enough, it might suffer extensive mental trauma at the GM's discretion.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature is initially @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2}.

Watcher in the Wastes.name: Watcher in the Wastes
Watcher in the Wastes.descriptionHazard: A massive sculpture of a wolflike form as tall as a mountain guards passage to the Cold Wastes at the northern end of Leng and seems almost ready to come to life at the approach of any creatures.
Watcher in the Wastes.disable: @Check[stealth|dc:51] (master) to avoid the initial notice of the gigantic form, or @Check[occultism|dc:48] (legendary) to know the proper posture and hand sign to make to turn away the watcher's attention
Watcher in the Wastes.stealth: (master) to realize the mountain is dangerous (DC 0 to see the towering statue in the first place)

action->Dreadful Notice.name: Dreadful Notice
action->Dreadful Notice.description:
Trigger A creature comes within a mile of the mountain-sized statue's base

Effect While the Watcher does not actually animate, it fills the triggering creature's mind with the dread conviction that it might do so at any moment. The triggering creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:42] save, after which they are temporarily immune to that particular Watcher's Dreadful Notice for 24 hours.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 24 hours.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3} (unlimited duration).

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} with fear with an unlimited duration; as long as the creature remains paralyzed, they need not drink or eat. If they are brought to a location where they no longer have line of sight to the watcher, the paralyzed creature can attempt a new Will save every day to recover from the paralysis, but during this time they are subject to thirst and starvation as normal.

Zutha's Legacy.name: Zutha's Legacy
Zutha's Legacy.descriptionHazard: The scowling visage of Runelord Zutha appears above the altar. Meanwhile, mask-like versions of Zutha's face manifest on nearby rubble and vomit swarms of maggots. Once the masks are destroyed, the air fills with spectral duplicates of Zutha's life-draining bone scythe.
Zutha's Legacy.disable: @Check[occultism|dc:45] (legendary) or Religion (legendary) to exorcise Zutha's spirit, or @Check[intimidation|dc:48] (master) or @Check[performance|dc:48] (master) to recite the details of Zutha's defeat; six total successes are required to disable the haunt.
Zutha's Legacy.reset: The haunt deactivates once no living creatures remain nearby. The haunt resets 1 hour later.
Zutha's Legacy.routine: (4 actions) The haunt uses Vomit Maggot three times, then Poisonous Belch once. For each success at Disabling the haunt, the haunt loses one Vomit Maggot action. Destroying a mask also removes one of the haunt's Vomit Maggot actions. Once the haunt can no longer use Vomit Maggot, it immediately regains three actions and replaces Vomit Maggot with Spectral Scythe. Destroying a scythe also removes one of the haunt's Spectral Scythe actions. Once the haunt loses all three of its Spectral Scythe actions, the haunt is destroyed.
Zutha's Legacy.stealth: (expert) to sense Zutha's hungry spirit before it manifests

action->Howl of Rage.name: Howl of Rage
action->Howl of Rage.description:
Trigger A living creature attempts to descend the stairwell at area A1 a into the islet's interior

Effect A ghostly version of Zutha's face appears above the island. Meanwhile, the rubble on the islet warps into smaller versions of Zutha's face. The faces howl in rage as one. All creatures on the islet must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:42] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} on a critical failure). The haunt then rolls initiative.

action->Vomit Maggot.name: Vomit Maggot
action->Vomit Maggot.description: One of Zutha's rubble-masks vomits a swarm of maggots. (The masks appear everywhere on the islet, and destroyed masks reform moments later, making nowhere on the islet safe.) The maggots burrow into the flesh of a creature of the GM's choice. The creature takes @Damage[2d12[persistent,piercing]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:42|basic] save) and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for as long as they continue taking this damage. When the persistent damage ends, the maggots dissolve into foul-smelling oil.

action->Spectral Scythe.name: Spectral Scythe
action->Spectral Scythe.description:
One of Zutha's scythes swipes at a creature of the GM's choice. The creature must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:42] save with the following results.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[(3d10+10)[void]] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[(6d10+10)[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[(12d10+10)[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2}.

action->Poisonous Belch.name: Poisonous Belch
action->Poisonous Belch.description:
The ghostly image of Zutha's face belches a toxic cloud that reeks of decaying flesh. The cloud fills a @Template[type:burst|distance:10] centered anywhere on the island and lasts until the haunt's next turn. Any creature that enters the area or that starts its turn in the area must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:44] save with the following results.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[5d8[poison]|options:area-damage] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[10d8[poison]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[20d8[poison]|options:area-damage] damage, is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}, and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for as long as it remains sickened.
